Comment: being the romantic fool that I am, my heart always jumps up at ancient opening styles; this is the Alekhine Defense, cooked up a century ago, by one of the greatest world champions ever... White has virtually no other options than e5...

preparing Nf3, the Flohr approach; we keep an eventual c4 for later use...

not how Alekhine meant this; most theory follows with e6, Nf3, or d6... this will end up in Sicilian variations for White, after dxc5, Qa5+...
the best move; all else is failing...

the best move; all else is failing...
a bit uncautious, considering Whites' next plan of action; better is Qc6, Nbd2, e6...

overlooking Whites' next opportunity completely; best course of action is a6 (blocks Nb5), Bd3 (Nxf5?, Nxc3!, Nd6+, Qxd6), Nc6, 0-0, Nxd4, cxd4, or directly Nc6, Nb5, Qa5...

no rocket science involved here: Nxg7+ is a nasty threat, and g6 does not work after Ng7+ and Bh6; after exf5, of course Qxd5... after Bf8, Nd6+, Bxd6, exd6...
I liked this better than Nfd4; Black cannot afford Nxd5, exd5, Qxd5+...

putting White in control...
putting White in control...
putting White in control...
putting White in control...
Black has not much choice left; after b6, Qd2, Ng6, Bxc5, bxc5, or Bxe3, fxe3, Ng6, White takes control with Qd6...
Qb3, Rb8 leads to nothing; we need to keep Black occupied... after Rxf4, Qd2...
after Rf8, Qe3! (0-0-0, b5!), Rxf3 is not of much use anymore; and after b5, simply Ncd2 is solving all problems... this is Blacks' last chance to unbalance Whites' game...

now after b5, Nd6, Nxe5, 0-0-0...
best here is b5, Nd6, Nxe5, 0-0-0, b4, Qd4, Bxd6, Qxd6, Qxd6, Rxd6, bxc3, bxc3, Nf7... now, Black is trading his only active piece at this point in development...
a bit better is Qf6 (mainly preventing Qg5), f4, d5, Bh3, Qh6, 0-0, Bc5!, Qxc5, Qxh3...

as was to be expected...

not of real use is Qd2, d5, and Blacks' game is opening up... this is the only way, to stir up some attack; after Bxf2, Bd3!, Whites' development is suddenly completed and ready for a Kings' attack via Rg1, Bxg1, Rxg1, or Rd2, Bc5, Rg2... after d5 (the only option to guard g6), always Bd3; the Black King is getting into trouble, with both Kings' pawns under attack...
not the best way to handle this; the safest way is Bd6, Kb1 (to get out of checks), g6, Rhg1, Qf7, h4, Bf4... this gives White an opportunity that cannot be missed...

the threat Qe8 is too potent, to let just slip by; so black has to act... this gives White the opportunity to displace the Black pieces...
